issues.title: Signature data not found.
issues.body:
# IMPORTANT

* [ x ] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/owncloud/news/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and followed the provided tips

## Explain the Problem
Owncloud returns error:
Some files have not passed the integrity check. Further information on how to resolve this issue can be found in our documentation. (List of invalid files… / Rescan…)
- news
	- EXCEPTION
		- OC\IntegrityCheck\Exceptions\InvalidSignatureException
		- Signature data not found.


## Steps to Reproduce
Explain what you did to encounter the issue
1. Install the news app as directed using news.tar.gz package
2. Uncompress the news package to owncloud/apps/
3. Change the ownership and group of news folder to www-data

## System Information
* News app version: 8.8.0 
* ownCloud version: 10.0.2
* PHP version: 7.0.22
* Database and version: MySQL
* Browser and version: Firefox
* Distribution and version: Ubuntu 16.04


Also, I cannot find News in owncloud Market or Apps menu, is it working as intended?

issues.title: "OCP\AppFramework\Db\DoesNotExistException" when no (unread) articles exist
issues.body:
## Explain the Problem
OwnCloud log shows ```Error	index	OCP\AppFramework\Db\DoesNotExistException: Did expect one result but found none when executing: query "SELECT `items`.* FROM `*PREFIX*news_items` `items` JOIN `*PREFIX*news_feeds` `feeds` ON `feeds`.`id` = `items`.`feed_id` AND `feeds`.`deleted_at` = 0 AND `feeds`.`user_id` = ? AND `items`.`id` = ? LEFT OUTER JOIN `*PREFIX*news_folders` `folders` ON `folders`.`id` = `feeds`.`folder_id` WHERE `feeds`.`folder_id` = 0 OR `folders`.`deleted_at` = 0 ORDER BY `items`.`id` DESC"; parameters Array ( [0] => Username [1] => 13490 ) ; limit ""; offset ""```

## Steps to Reproduce
Sync feeds with iOS app "CloudNews". This results in above pasted error.

## System Information
* News app version: 2.0.2
* ownCloud version: 10.0.1.2
* PHP version: 5.6
* Database and version: MySQL 5.5.55
* Browser and version: not relevant
* Distribution and version: not relevant

What does the error log entry want to let me know? That SQL statement is too much for my basic SQL knowledge :-(

issues.title: Add retry button for failed feeds
issues.body:
## Explain the Problem
There is no retry button for broken feeds and it seems that a failed feed won't be retried even if the server got fixed.

## Steps to Reproduce
Explain what you did to encounter the issue
1. Add a feed
2. Hope that the feed will break (because the server is not accessible)
3. The feed has a yellow background and when you move the cursor on it, there is the title `Update failed more than 50 times...`
4. Fix the server providing the feed
5. I don't know what to do to get the feed working again

## System Information
* News app version: `9.0.4`
* ownCloud version: `9.1.4.2`
* PHP version: `7.0.15`
* Database and version: `mariadb 10.0.29`
* Browser and version: `firefox 51.0.1`
* Distribution and version: `ubuntu 16.04.2`

issues.title: Display feed icon in articles
issues.body:
* [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/owncloud/news/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and followed the provided tips

## Explain the Problem
When reading news on the website (e.g. "unread articles") it's hard to see to which feed a article belongs to. There is only the feed title written in light grey below the article title.
I think it would be better to display the icon of the feed next to the feed title.

* News app version: `9.0.4`
* ownCloud version: `9.1.2`

issues.title: Modify feed URLs in user interface
issues.body:
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/owncloud/news/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and followed the provided tips

Some feeds changes their feed URL from time to time (e.g. moving to `https://`). I found no option to change the URL of existing feeds.

I'd suggest adding a button to the context menu of feeds to change the feed URL (it's possible to change the name of the feed but not the URL).

It would be nice if there was an option to turn off images on mobile data connections.

issues.title: Feed http-auth settings may accidently leak owncloud login to 3rd party sites
issues.body:
The input fields used in the expandable  _Advanced settings_ panel contain input elements for Username and Password that will be used to retrieve the feed over HTTP.

Since the two input elements for username and password use the same "name" parameter as the ones in the owncloud login, at least my firefox and chrome auto-fill them as soon as they appear (after I expanded the _Advanced settings_).
## Steps to Reproduce

Explain what you did to encounter the issue
1. Save your OC login credentials in the browser
2. Go to the news app, Subscribe to new feed
3. Click on _Advanced settings_ and watch if the browser auto-fills your OC credentials for this feed.
## Implications

This behavior can lead the user to accidentally expose his OC login credentials to the feed provider.
At the same time it risks that the users password is stored in plain-text in the OC database.
## System Information
- News app version: 8.8.0
- ownCloud version: nextcloud 9.0.53
- Browser and version: Firefox 48.0 / Chromium Version 52.0.2743.116

Those errors are from caldav & cardav.
I have check:

```
Check if the config.ini in owncloud/data/news/config/config.ini contains useCronUpdates = true
Check if you are using the system cron (Cron) setting on the admin page. AJAX and Web cron will not update feeds
Check if the cronjob exists with crontab -u www-data -e (replace www-data with your httpd user)
Check the file permissions of the cron.php file and if www-data (or whatever your httpd user is called like) can read and execute that script
Check if you can execute the cron with sudo -u www-data php -f owncloud/cron.php (replace www-data with your httpd user)
Check your data/owncloud.log for errors
Check if the cronjob is ever executed by placing an error_log('updating'); in the background job file. If the cronjob runs, there should be an updating log statement in your httpd log.
If there is no updating statement in your logs check if your cronjob is executed by executing a different script
If your cron works fine but owncloud's cronjobs are never executed, file a bug in core
```

Cron execute fine, he is logged into administration page.

Thx for the help :)

issues.title: Published time on feeds
issues.body:
Hi,

First of all thanks for this great app!
Yesterday i have migrated from Feedly to ownCloud News app.
Eveything seems fine except a "problem" with the items timestamp.

Feedly seems to be based on the `<published>` feed tag and ownCloud News is based on the `<updated>` feed tag to create the item timestamp.

![ownnote](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1951866/14762157/02bb1a90-0974-11e6-8fed-a1e7f8bf994b.png)

![feedly](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1951866/14762158/05bb33ec-0974-11e6-8667-a2f90ebcb3dc.png)

![rss](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1951866/14762185/a4a50ab4-0974-11e6-8b21-fc5eeb7b098b.png)

For example on a Youtube RSS feeds channels the updated timestamp is over and over updated so the timestamp is not accurate for me (see screenshots and [this feed](https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=UCR4s1DE9J4DHzZYXMltSMAg))

Is there an option to only display published date and not updated date in the column ?

I saw a bugfix on 4.2.0 release, maybe it is related ? :

> Ignore Atom updated tag if it is earlier than the published tag

ownCloud : 9.0.1
ownCloud News: 8.7.1

Thanks!

issues.title: API 2.0
issues.body:
In addition to the old APIs I'd like to modernize the API since it seems more complicated than it needs to be and a lot of REST things are used in a wrong way

The main goals are the following
- Move the shitty version in the URL from vX-X to a semantically versioned URL, e.g. /api/2.0.0/ or remove the version from the URL entirely by sending an HTTP request header (News-Api-Version: 2.0.0)
- Use HTTP cache headers instead of requiring you to pass a last modified date
- Crack down on the number of URLs, e.g. marking an item as read and starred would become 
  - **PATCH /items/1** 
  
  ``` json
  {"read": true, "starred": true, "fingerprint": "some_hash"}
  ```
- Actions on multiple resources should be handled at the correct endpoint, e.g. marking multiple items as read and starred would look like this: 
  - **PATCH /items** 
  
  ``` json
  [
    {"id": 123, "read": true, "starred": true, "fingerprint": "some_hash"}, 
    {"id": 124, "read": true, "starred": true, "fingerprint": "some_hash"}
  ]
  ```
- Get rid of the id vs feedid + guidhash difference. I thought this was useful once, but we did not need it
- Also implement a modified date for feeds and folders so you don't have to fetch everything all over again
- Provide helper routes to make syncing a breeze. You normally have three usecases, those should be reflected by three routes
  - Initial sync: Fetch feeds, folders, unread + starred items: **GET /api/2.0.0/sync**
  - Sync local changes (no return appart from errors because the next GET request fetches all changed items anyways):  **POST /api/2.0.0/sync** 
  
  ``` json
  {"items": [{"id": 1, "read": true, "fingerprint": "some_hash"}]}
  ```
  
    The fingerprint is a hash over the title, url, content and enclosures and if it is the same in the current database, only the status (read/starred) will be returned to the client.
  - Checking for new contents without changes:: **GET /api/2.0.0/sync**  + http cache headers

The response will be the changes.

Furthermore creating feeds/folders that already exist should respond with the existing object instead of just returning an error message. This makes it very easy to create folders: you just submit the contents and if you get a 409 you just use the returned contents.

Ideas? Suggestions?

@David-Development @phedlund @icewind1991 @jangernert @cosenal

issues.title: Automatically load in news items
issues.body:
After using the app for a while i im a bit annoyed that the items arent loaded in automatically. I was always against this loading but i think we can do it in a way thats useful and wont break/interfere much.

I'd suggest that it automatically loads in the newest items once:
- The scrollbar is on the top or
- The scrollbar is in the lower area and all articles are read (loading in new items will scroll to the top in that case)
- The app is inactive and the tab gets active again (visibiltiy api: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1060008/is-there-a-way-to-detect-if-a-browser-window-is-not-currently-active)

That way it wont load in new items while you're reading but will silently update the view in the background for you :)

cc @jancborchardt @cosenal @icewind1991

ok, thanks I think i got the problem:

Theres some kind of racecondition when you mark a feed read while it updates. The following happens:
- It requests a feed update, its adding the feeds and calculating the new unread count
- Now you fire a mark feed read request
- the update request comes back and tells you the new unreadcount which is not valid actually
- your mark feed read request finishes, but the new unread count is wrong.

Can you try if the newest commit fixed your problem? I now always return the unreadcount as 0 from a mark as read request. It can still happen that an update request finishes earlier and sets the unreadcount to some number, but it should be reset to 0 instantly after the mark read request finishes.

This is a downside for immediately showing the read feedback instead of waiting for the server response first to set it because it means that it can get out of sync cc @jancborchardt 

Another possible scenario would be that the count database request counts while the read feed request sets the items as unread (although im not sure if i can fix that)

The thing is that you cant do any CSRF checks when using subscriblets. This can basically give attackers the opportunity to let you subscribe to any page by either visiting a page or clicking a link. If we have a vulnerability in our or simple pies code this can be used to exploit it. cc @LukasReschke

So essentially, at the least it will be a bookmark. An amazing fallback would be iFraming the site and showing an slight error overlay bar on top. That way you don’t even have to click a link but can just read the site anyway.

On one hand I think it’s a good idea, on the other hand Twitter supports RSS (albeit hidden) and I think specific Twitter and Google+ support is out of scope for a News reader here.

There could be an ownCloud social media app for Twitter, Google+, Facebook etc. Then again that would just power proprietary networks which have their own web apps in the first place, and we need to decide what we should focus on.

So yeah, I’d actually say here use the RSS link @Radiation mentioned. If Twitter turns that off, shame on them. But implementing native Twitter support is too much work for too little benefit (closing this hence). If you want to do it, go ahead though, you can code up an app. :)

Yeah, ideally on both content (refresh current feed only) and navigation (refresh all). Maybe it’s good to use [hook.js](http://usehook.com/) by @jordansinger for this.

(Btw @Raydiation I wouldn’t necessarily consider this for alpha stage already.)
Sounds good.

@Raydiation did you check out #9?
- The »error« and feed entry should be persistent, even after reload.
- Background color should probably be yellow (and black text), not very obtrusive red
- only one line, with the website title (or something) and the i icon.
- clicking on the entry shows an error info in the content area (»Sorry, there were problems adding the site. Maybe it doesn’t have a feed or there are some errors in it. You can go to the site directly: (link)«)
- and if possible, even directly iframe the page. Of course only if it was a valid URL. If it wasn’t, the client-side checks should already fail

TL;DR: At worst, an erroneous feed becomes a bookmark.

I agree with Alessandro. Just remove the entry client side as soon as
server side detects is a duplicate, and ideally highlight the already
existing feed. (when its in the case of adding a single site, could also
scroll the left bar to that original entry)

On Saturday, April 13, 2013, Bernhard Posselt wrote:

> I see. A way to get that to the client is to simply throw a BLException in
> the feed creation part. This has to be improved :)
> https://github.com/owncloud/news/blob/master/bl/feedbl.php#L61
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/owncloud/news/issues/61#issuecomment-16331619
> .

If we do one or the other (full feed, or »read more«), it will definitely be a default and no preference. Let’s instead try and find a solution which works well, instead of offloading design decisions to every single user.

Newsblur has the cut articles and »Read more« functions, and I find it really annoying. I’m with @Raydiation on this. Rather than the read-more-wall, we could add very subtle half-transparent buttons on the bottom right or so which let you quickly go to the next article – if you’re not familiar with keyboard shortcuts.

If you want to quickly skim, use shortcuts (to come). If you want to properly read, scroll.

@psych0d0g regarding your idea to just do it for top-level folders or for »all unread« – initially this might seem good, but actually the split is a bit strange. I change lots of times between reading just one feed, and a folder, and all articles, and a change of mode just based on that would be very confusing.

TL;DR: Let’s wait for keyboard shortcuts, and maybe have some visual help in the manner of an unobtrusive »next« button on the side if an article is particularly long (longer than 2 screen heights for instance).

@psych0d0g yes, and we have plenty of ideas for sure, many of which we already considered and either developed or discarded. Keep in mind that we want to keep everything simple. People should not need to tweak settings or change anything to get a good software. And the content, the sites should always be in focus, not obstructed by interface elements.

@psych0d0g check out http://newsblur.com and their http://dev.newsblur.com – there they have »List View« which is very similar to what you mean.

@Raydiation and making people’s lives easier is why we write code in the first place. If we just write a bit of code, lives are actually made worse by shitty software. So we need to push forward and actually make it better. :)
@raghunayyar let’s from now on only use px for new code, no em. :) Transition step by step makes it much easier.

Honestly I don’t think this algorithm makes sense for the News app unread count. It’s different from email in that it’s not personal, and it’s different from file size in the Files app because there’s no real absolute value. 5 unread items can mean completely different things for two feeds. So I’d say we should remove that opacity-unread stuff again.

What might be good on the other hand is if the feed opacity would change according to the latest update. That is, feeds which haven’t been updated will be more transparent the older the latest update is. That way you quickly see which feeds are kind of stale (although the algorithm shouldn’t be too sensitive). This could also be applied to titles of feeds as you scroll through it in the past. Thoughts?
Similarly, adding a new feed to the root folder should put it at the very top, so you actually see it being added. If it’s added at the bottom of the list there’s no feedback.
And »Discard« should also be »Delete site«.

review_comments.body: Yeah, I also don't like it so much here. But let me explain: The main things done here are turning relative image-/favicon-paths in absolute URLs and the deletion of the attachments of feeds/items. - the deletion of attachments can actually be done in the business layer, so i agree here and I will move the functionality - but the URLs have to be modified on every request of an item (resp. feed). If this is not done here, every business layer function that returns items (resp. feeds) must do this (e.g. call a modifyURLs-function). So I think it could be better to do it at a central point right after they get out of the database.?

Yes, I think you are right here, even if I don't like the idea of loading every image by PHP. This is definitely a bottleneck for feeds with many images and "small" servers. Ideally the request will be handled solely by the HTTP-server via its rewrite-engine. Is it possible to provide a .htaccess-file with the News app? Then we could use the functionality here as fallback.

It is activated by default (www.php.net/manual/en/simplexml.installation.php).
But because it can be disabled and to keep the code uniform, I better switch to domdocument. ;)

- saving the images in the standard data directory and serving via AppFramework response (optionally providing advice in the wiki how to configure the HTTP-server to handle the image requests)
Yes, it is doing exactly this already.?

Oh, I wanted to change that, thanks!

Just to clarify:
The problem is, that images must be served without user credentials. So I wanted at least some degree of obfuscation in the URL. It is md5( itemID + feedID + feedGUID ) at the moment, but I will put some random in the image file name instead.

Yeah, I'll put that in a function.

There's no global parameter for the URL root of owncloud, especially none you can use to determine the absolute URL for cached images (favicons) while the feeds are imported (via cron). That's why the absolute paths are set on request.

Since no information about prefetched images are saved in the db at the moment, the images (and favicon) of a feed are saved in folder named by the feed ID. That's why the feed is saved first to get the ID. Then the favicon is stored.

Same for the items btw.
You mean I should add a function to save the icon locally there?
I don't mean obfuscation in the code, but by generating a random URL per image. In the end it is the same as in the public sharing functionality of owncloud.
